page.title: 05LANHYDROCK HOUSE
page.content: Much of the house remains as it was when it was occupied by the family. The rooms range from the dining-room, laid for dinner with priceless silver and porcelain, to the servants' quarters where the bedrooms are small and strictly utilitarian. Visitors are allowed to see most of the house either as members of the National Trust, having paid a subscription, or as visitors, having paid an entry fee. The outstanding room is the original, seventeenth century gallery with its plaster barrel ceiling which portrays incidents from Old Testament history. It is here that {Entertainment}takes place in the winter months, such as concerts, plays, social events. Behind the house is the church which is now one of a group under the care of the parish of Lostwithiel.
